fyi, when someone says they spent years researching flat earth, it means for years they have watched the same exact talking points being made over and over again on 15-20 min random yt videos and never once just asked google some simple questions. thats why they always say you cant go to antartica, no1 ever flys over the poles and all this lying nonsense.

at first when i heard of the flat earther's i though it was a joke thing, an excuse for people to get together and have some laughs and a good time. it took me a while to figure out that they were dead serious. thing is i have personally seen several of the other planets through telescopes i would find it odd for earth to be the only exception in our solar system while every other planet i can see with my own eyes through a telescope is spherical. even in the age of sail, charts and calculations are based on a spherical world. if the world was flat then based on those charts no one would have been able to get anywhere once they lost sight of land. once again pointing out in the age of sail, masts of ship were what was spotted first of any ship. as a science experiment when living in california, we got a boat and we marked off lines on the mast to see if we could calculate when what portions of the mast would dip beneath the horizon. our calculations were almost dead on when we ran our experiment. the results would have been impossible for us to calculate if the world was flat.

i'm definitely not a flat earther, but flat earth is a great topic to bring up the discussion of how mainstream science has given us false and true information throughout history. even at the same time. usually correcting itself because we just didn't know enough at the time.
there were times when people didn't know about germ theory . they theorized sickness and infection was caused by "miasma" - an invisible poisonous vapor caused by decaying organic matter. it sounds right, and goes off intuition. they were obviously wrong - but they were just teetering on the edge of microbiology. they just didn't have the tools to discover germs yet and prove or expand on their theories.
and that's all most of our understanding of the world is. theories that we've developed from what we can understand and discover at this moment. we do tend to set aside the 5% we can't understand because what else can we do - but that might just be the key to discovering a law from our theories.
it is strange how quantum mechanics leaves so much unanswered in regards to the theory of relativity. i refuse to believe we have even half the answers we think we do.

most of the flat maps are due to the curvature of the earth being inpossible to copy down the exact correct porportions onto a flat map. so you can either look at sections of the earth at a time, or have a whole map where the scaling is enlarged the further away from the equator you are (which is why greenland looks comparble to africa but in reality is only 1/14 the size)
the moon's orbit is not perfectly circular (which nullifies his point anyways) and is complicated but the earth and the moon both orbit the sun, and the moon cannot escape the local gravity of earth.
he was actually right about the 3 miles dropping 6 feet but light reffracts around the surface of the earth and can cause it to bend back down. this is why you can see slightly further than 3 miles, but far less than he was trying to convince you.
his gravational model honestly didnt make sense to me so idk about that
the pressure argument was a good question but earth's gravity is still very strong (if you were 300 miles up in the air you would only weigh a few kess pounds) so the gas is safely trapped. moreover, we know the pressure decreases as your elevation increases and the "force" from pressure only cares about the pressure difference between a spot. so really high up in the atmopshere its weak pressure and so there really isnt much trying to escape anyway, but gravity can easily hold everything down from the surface to the edge of space (where atmosphere is essentially gone)

3:09 that's not what gravity is gravity and that's not what dark energy does

lets just address the bs dave was talking about with gravity.
1. there is no one molecule or atom that is like "im the center of mass", theres just a point that is the center of mass, which isnt anything physical, but just a mathematical calculation based on the relative locations of all the particles with mass.
2. there is enough gravity to hold the solar system together. no one is claiming dark matter is necessary to hold the solar system together. based on our current models, something like dark matter, or a quantum gravity model, is required to explain how galaxies form and stay together, as well as why the much, much, much larger inter galactic structures behave the way they do. beyond that, even if the model is wrong, which it might be (the point of science is to find out what is true and what isnt and the model being wrong just means you need a better model), that doesnt mean the observations are wrong.
